[3]imprisonment but because it was my first day at school.... 
[4]There was never any pretense that the gorgeous, vital, clever, temperamental animal that was my mother ever for a heartbeat considered having any life of her own. She ignored all her needs and was alive only for me. It was terrific. At the time. 
[5]"One tear..only one...so make it a good one." This was my mother's instruction to me. 
[6]My mother dealt with our considerable problems of survival by talking..Always she discovered her own best thoughts by sifting through her own words. 
[7]Each night my mother promised me a wonderful life.. Each night I looked for a new expressive way to tell my mother how much I loved her. 
[8]I just played and did my lessons and every time I looked up my mother was in the process of saving us. 
[9]Desperation in her hands was our weapon. 
[10]With this weapon she had her marriage annulled - usually impossible for the poor - and somehow convinced an associate of my father's to transport two Mexicans North in style. 
[11]My mother's prayer for us, which she made me repeat exactly, represented a stunning look into our future. "Please God, let only the bad things change." 
[12]My mother had redefined her own passions. Blaming herself for the father she gave me, she would never again be lured by a man's rough edges..She had decided that goodness would be her catnip. 
[13]At the time, I was oblivious to my mother's anguish. She loved and lived to talk. Now, as if by a witch's spell, words were no longer her bridge but her barrier. In a very real sense she feared she had left herself behind. 
[14]We moved into a place managed by my mother's aunt. My mother worked two jobs in two local stores paying a total of 450 dollars a week... 
[15]..just ever so barely enough. 
[16]But we were fine. We had it down. If only I could have stayed six. 
[17]That quickly it was clear she could no longer work two jobs and leave me to my own at night. The following morning she did something about it. A boy I never saw again had changed our lives. 
[18]I will major in linguistics and make sociology my sub- concentration. Because it has been my experience that the barriers of 
[19]language are more than we dare admit. That, as much as we translate, finally we will never understand each other. My mother's name, for example, beautiful in Spanish, becomes leaden and awful when pronounced by a non-Latin. 
[20]My mother did not understand her male boss. His heart was good and he was rare in not flirting with her. But they were starkly different. Privacy and dignity were the same word to my mother. Naturally, when she found herself sitting next to a man who cried over his child's hurt she had no idea how to process the event. 
[21]The job was taxing her. She had no template for confusion let alone frustration. 
[22]It was so unusual for my mother to ask my help that I realized immediately she was losing her battle to be uninvolved with the Claskys. 
[23]Our culture embraces fullness in a woman. You, the women of the admissions committee, as intelligent as you are, have no idea how casual and complete such acceptance is back home, in the land of the size 16 bikini. 
[24]This is one of the cultural differences between us which I wish to explore academically at Princeton. American women, I believe, actually feel the same as Hispanic women about weight. 
[25]....a desire for the comfort of fullness. 
[26]And, when that desire is suppressed for style and deprivation allowed to rule... 
[27]...dieting, exercising American women become afraid of everything associated with being curvaceous, such as wantonness, lustfulness, sex, food, motherhood..all that is good in life. 
[28]The first time one sees natural beauty which is owned by others confounds the senses.. I had never imagined the word "money" could be associated with anything but the anxiety of not having enough. I didn't know God had a toy store for the rich. 
[29]Learning English would cost five hundred and ninety nine dollars down and 15 monthly payments of one hundred and ten dollars...which represents 48 percent interest..Mexicans marketing Mexicans. But not a penny was wasted. 
[30]My mother showed an extraordinary facility for learning the language. 
[31]..as well as a totally committed, obsessive work ethic, which blocked out all else..She was her daughter's mother. 
[32]The experience was literally mind boggling. My mind did boggle. My cranial cells stunned. Even if I had enough sense of wonder to imagine such a school existed; my sense of fairness made it unthinkable that any school could offer this much more than my own.. 
[33]There is a terrible crisis which comes when your own personality is not equal to the challenge you face. When being who you are no longer works. 
[34]When people exist under one roof, a tiny society forms..the stuff of 
[35]novelas: masters and servants unconsciously dancing in lock step so that, when things go wrong, traumas converge. 
[36]My great Aunt Monica had finally managed to get her mother to Los Angeles and my mother was making a party. 
[37]I was with my friends who had helped me understand real optimism. 
[38]Though it is possible to judge harshly my conduct toward my mother in my first year at school; almost all professional literature excuses my behavior as developmental, since I was entering an age where rebellion and narcissism were to be expected. And I was being mentored. 
[39]My mother never told me the details of her visit to the restaurant. But she often referred to it as the greatest conversation of her life. 
[40]The first minute we were alone, my mother told me that I would no longer go to the private school. 
[41]My mother changed our lives once more. This time because she saw in me, to her great alarm, a character flaw of some size. She has taught me to be a watch dog of my character, to control my ambition. I am not quite there. 
[42]For that reason should you choose to grant me your scholarship my mother, at my request, will be relocating to the New York Metropolitan Area so that she can stay close during my time at Princeton. 
[43]I hope my essay has done her justice. I love her with all my heart.
